body: Additionally, calling `vim.system(...):wait()` from the winbar using `%!v:lua...` prevents `vim.lsp.hover` from closing. I suspect this issue is related to that bug.
Have you tried `vim.loop.spawn()` with `vim.wait()`? That should help reduce the bug further.

I get this rough stacktrace:

```
 0   libsystem_kernel.dylib        	       0x18822d11c __pthread_kill + 8
1   libsystem_pthread.dylib       	       0x188264cc0 pthread_kill + 288
2   libsystem_c.dylib             	       0x188174a40 abort + 180
3   nvim                          	       0x104e08080 loop_poll_events + 340
4   nvim                          	       0x104e9e7bc nlua_wait.llvm.4094449131833692778 + 1008
5   nvim                          	       0x104c53b7c lj_BC_FUNCC + 44
6   nvim                          	       0x104c69f00 lua_pcall + 228 (lj_api.c:1150)
7   nvim                          	       0x104cbed90 uv__run_timers + 44 (timer.c:178)
8   nvim                          	       0x104cc1fd0 uv_run + 596 (core.c:465)
9   nvim                          	       0x104e08048 loop_poll_events + 284
10  nvim                          	       0x104e631e4 vgetorpeek.llvm.16489879637176251020 + 1548
11  nvim                          	       0x104f1ad3c normal_check.llvm.4562386351950554467 + 1356
12  nvim                          	       0x10500eb38 state_enter + 108
13  nvim                          	       0x104dd1020 main + 16348
14  dyld                          	       0x187ee90e0 start + 2360
```
Hmm, `vim.wait()` shouldn't be allowed in a fast context at all.
I'm sure you are right, but could you explain why?
Because `vim.wait()` runs the event loop, which cannot be run recursively...

Doesn't `vim.wait`already consider this with:

```vimhelp
      â€¢ {fast_only}  (boolean|nil) If true, only |api-fast| events will be
                     processed. If called from while in an |api-fast| event,
                     will automatically be set to `true`.
```

```c
  MultiQueue *loop_events = fast_only || in_fast_callback > 0
    ? main_loop.fast_events : main_loop.events;

```

I'm surprised we haven't seen this issue before.

Smaller reproducer:

```lua
vim.uv.timer_start(vim.uv.new_timer(), 0, 100, function()
  vim.wait(100, function()
  end, 100)
end)
```

rename.to: Calling `vim.wait` within fast events results in failure.

rename.from: Calling `vim.wait` within fast events results in failure.
rename.to: Calling `vim.wait` within fast events results in crash

body:
I'm not sure why `vim.wait` calls the main loop at all. From what I can tell it should always just process either the main events _or_ fast events via `multiqueue_process_events()`.

I think this bug happens because of:

```c
#define LOOP_PROCESS_EVENTS(loop, multiqueue, timeout) \
  do { \
    if (multiqueue && !multiqueue_empty(multiqueue)) { \
      multiqueue_process_events(multiqueue); \
    } else { \
      loop_poll_events(loop, timeout); \
    } \
  } while (0)
```

and we hit the `else` because `multiqueue` is empty.

issue.title: fix(lua): do not allow `vim.wait()` in fast callbacks

repository.name: neovim
repository.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

issue.body:
`vim.wait()` cannot be called in a fast callback since the main loop cannot be run in that context as it is not reentrant


Fixes #26122

body: The loop handling logic isn't particularly clear (maybe needs more docs), but _I think_ I now roughly understand it and this should be fixed in #26132
